Award.AwardTitle: Complex Bio-Nano-Dynamics of Motor Proteins in Dynamically Controlled Fluids

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The recent breathtaking advances in modern engineering and bioscience research have enabled the identification of properties and roles of biomolecules that power cellular processes. The hallmark of these nanoscale systems is their multi-scale organization. In neurodegenerative diseases for example, axonal degeneration occurs because the neurotransmitters do not reach the synapse correctly. This is because binding of kinesins on microtubules is hindered. Hence, interrogating the properties of the nanotransport done by kinesins on microtubules is crucial for early/presymptomatic diagnosis of neurodegenerative diseases. Such early diagnosis will be enabled the novel models developed in this work.

The goal of this work is to create an innovative approach to model and to actively interrogate the complex bio-nanotransport of groups of kinesins interacting with microtubules in controlled fluids. Specific aims are: (a) novel models: develop new models which bridge the gap between nano/pico length/time scales and macroscales through combined atomistic/continuum modeling and experiments, and (b) novel detection: create novel methods to interrogate kinesin-MT systems about their properties by monitoring the nanotransport done by these systems in controlled fluids. Uniquely combined theoretical and experimental methods from atomistic simulations, nonlinear dynamics and bioengineering are used.

This effort will answer important scientific questions, and will impact applications spanning from cell science to biomolecular nanotechnology and engineered biodevices. For example, understanding how to model motor proteins in controlled fluids and how to identify properties of nanotransport in vivo is a key element in the next generation of drug technology and delivery, and can profoundly impact medicine. This work contributes to such understanding by using nonlinear dynamic approaches for solving very important questions in medicine and cell biology. If successful, this research can radically transform the way neurodegenerative diseases are diagnosed. Also, this work will provide fundamental understanding of bio-mechanochemical processes which affect the development of lab-on-a-chip bio-applications.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

Performance_Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this research, we have created an innovative approach to model and to actively interrogate the complex bio-nanotransport of groups of kinesins interacting with microtubules (MTs) in fluid media with controlled viscoelasticity. Specific outcomes include: (a) novel models: develop new models that bridge the gap between nano/pico length/time scales and macroscales through combined atomistic/continuum modeling and experiments, and (b) novel detection: create novel methods to sense/interrogate kinesin-MT systems about their properties by monitoring the nanotransport done by these systems in fluid media with controlled fluctuations in viscoelasticity. In particular, this research has lead to: (1) development of new methods to identify and actively control the viscoelasticity of bio-fluids, (2) development of innovative models of kinesin-MT interaction in fluids with temporal fluctuations in viscoelasticity, (3) creation of novel damaged MTs and develop unique approaches to detect these damages by interrogating kinesin-MT dynamics.

 

This research has provided a novel computation model for understanding the interaction between kinesin and altered microtubules. The work has developing and implementing theoretically and computationally novel mechano-chemical models of kinesins moving along axons along microtubules with obstacles. The research has provided new insights into the binding and unbinding of kinesin to microtubules in the presence of obstacles on the microtubules. A single kinesin molecule is able to transport its cargo about 1 μm in the absence of external loads along a track with no obstacles. However, kinesins face obstacles in their transport, and yet they perform much longer-range transport in cells by working collectively.

 

The long-range transport by a team of kinesins is surprising because the motion of the cargo in cells can be hindered by other particles. To reveal how the kinesins are able to accomplish their tasks of transport in harsh intracellular circumstances, stochastic studies on the kinesin motion were performed by considering the binding and unbinding of kinesins to microtubules and their dependence on the presence of obstacles on the microtubules. The unbinding probabilities corresponding to each mechanochemical state of kinesin were modeled. The statistical characterization of the instants and locations of binding were captured by computing the probability of unbound kinesin being at given locations. Starting from experimental data, the model predicts overall transport characteristics such as the run length that play a crucial role in neurodegenerative diseases. First, our study has characterized that the interaction between the walking kinesins and moving or unmovable kinesins. Using that interaction, the effects of other motors on kinesins are predicted when they move on the same microtubule. If several kinesins share one microtubule together, their velocities are almost not affected by other kinesins on the microtubule. These results suggest that cells can handle several intracellular transport processes effectively with a small number of microtubules. However, both the velocity and run length decrease considerably in the presence of unmovable kinesins. Thus, the malfunction of a few motors could degrade the whole transport system. Our studies have shown also that the run length is affected by the presence of obstacles, and varies non-monotonically over the forces applied on the cargo. In addition, the transport velocity for teams of kinesins is lower than that of a single molecule but is not significantly influenced by the presence of obstacles. These results provide a starting point for the development of biomarkers and methods to detect shortening run lengths as indicators of deficient neural nanotransport. Moreover, we have predicted that a group of kinesins has a more efficient transport than a single kinesin from the perspective of velocity and run length. This suggests that the behavior of kinesins under large loads prevents the early termination of the transport that can be caused by the interference with the static or moving obstacles.

 

The effects of obstacles on the motion of kinesins are important because several neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and Huntington's disease may be related to an abnormal intracellular transport. In addition, negative effects of obstacles on the intracellular transport have been observed in vivo. Specifically, the transport of various types of cargoes was decelerated or failed due to an excessive number of tau proteins. Thus, the characterization of the motion of kinesins in the presence of tau proteins is necessary to reveal quantitative relations related to neurodegenerative diseases and tau proteins. Our diffusion model can be used to obtain such relations between tau proteins and the motion of kinesins. This makes an impact because early diagnostic of deficiencies in mechanical nanotransport inside cells can revolutionize the diagnosis and management of neurodegenerative diseases. According to recent NIH studies of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), 5% earlier detection of AD could lead to a 50% reduction in mortality. In AD, hyperphosphorylated tau protein affects neuronal transport, leads to beta-amyloid peptide deposition, and synaptic malfunction. An early effect of hyperphosphorylated tau protein is a deficient mechanical transport executed by motor proteins such as kinesins along microtubules.

Modified by: Bogdan I Epureanu

Image
  • Various processes during axonal transport are captured by the novel models, including the effects of obstacles created by tau proteins.
    University of Michigan, Applied Nonlinear Dynamics of Multi-Scale Systems Lab
    Copyrighted
    Bogdan I Epureanu
    Dynamics of axonal transport

Specific outcomes include: (a) novel models: develop new models that bridge the gap between nano/pico length/time scales and macroscales through combined atomistic/continuum modeling and experiments, and (b) novel detection: create novel methods to sense/interrogate kinesin-MT systems about their properties by monitoring the nanotransport done by these systems in fluid media with controlled fluctuations in viscoelasticity. In AD, hyperphosphorylated tau protein affects neuronal transport, leads to beta-amyloid peptide deposition, and synaptic malfunction. An early effect of hyperphosphorylated tau protein is a deficient mechanical transport executed by motor proteins such as kinesins along microtubules.
